unnormalised: ## My Adventures in Family Court: Or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Lawyer
normalised: ## My Adventures in Family Court: Or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Lawyer

unnormalised: So, picture this: yours truly, usually found happily wrestling code into submission, suddenly finds myself staring down the barrel of a family court case. Turns out, "irreconcilable differences" sounds so much more sophisticated than "she got tired of my Star Wars figurine collection, especially the life-sized Darth Vader." Whatever, right? Divorce it is! But navigating the legal jungle? Oy vey!
normalised: So, picture this: yours truly, usually found happily wrestling code into submission, suddenly finds myself staring down the barrel of a family court case. Turns out, "irreconcilable differences" sounds so much more sophisticated than "she got tired of my Star Wars figurine collection, especially the life-sized Darth Vader." Whatever, right? Divorce it is! But navigating the legal jungle? Oy vey!

unnormalised: First off, the lingo. I swear, they speak a different language in those hallowed halls. My lawyer, Adv. Sharma (bless her patient soul), kept tossing around terms like "alimony," "custody," and "Section 125 CrPC." I felt like I needed a decoder ring just to understand what was going on. Turns out "alimony" isn't some fancy Italian dessert (sadly), and "custody" doesn't involve keeping someone locked in a cupboard (double sadly).
normalised: First off, the lingo. I swear, they speak a different language in those hallowed halls. My lawyer, Advocate Sharma (bless her patient soul), kept tossing around terms like "alimony," "custody," and "Section one hundred and twenty five C-R-P-C." I felt like I needed a decoder ring just to understand what was going on. Turns out "alimony" isn't some fancy Italian dessert (sadly), and "custody" doesn't involve keeping someone locked in a cupboard (double sadly).

unnormalised: Then there's the paperwork. Oh, the paperwork! Forms in triplicate, affidavits longer than my arm, financial statements that would make even a chartered accountant weep. I think I single-handedly saved the Indian paper industry with my divorce proceedings. I had to list every asset, from my ₹5000 savings account to my prized collection of vintage comics. Apparently, Spider-Man is considered "marital property." Who knew?

unnormalised: The courtroom itself was like a scene from a bad Bollywood movie. Dramatic pronouncements, hushed whispers, and enough tension to cut with a butter knife. I half-expected someone to burst into song and dance at any moment. My ex's lawyer, a Mr. Kapoor with a perfectly coiffed mustache, looked like he'd stepped straight out of a 70s film. He kept referring to me as "a man consumed by frivolous hobbies" which, honestly, is a fair assessment.

unnormalised: Speaking of my ex, let's just say things were... heated. We haggled over everything, from the ownership of the microwave to who got to keep the dog (a fluffy Pomeranian named Princess Leia, naturally). It was like a high-stakes auction, except the prizes were custody of a canine and a questionable kitchen appliance. The judge, a stern-looking lady with the patience of a saint, looked like she was about to pull her hair out.

unnormalised: The best part? The legal fees. Let's just say Adv. Sharma's hourly rate made my eyes water. I'm pretty sure I could have bought a small island in the Andamans with the money I spent on legal counsel. But hey, at least I got to keep my Darth Vader. Priorities, people! The initial retainer was ₹50000, and that was just the beginning.

unnormalised: So, what's the moral of this story? Don't marry someone who hates your Star Wars collection. Or, if you do, be prepared for a long, expensive, and utterly ridiculous legal battle. On the bright side, I'm now an expert in family law terminology and have a newfound appreciation for the joys of singlehood. Plus, I get to display my life-sized Darth Vader without any judgmental stares. Win-win, right? The final judgement came on 15/08/2023.
